CatDescriptText: Nelva Thomas, housewife, Washington and Mary Thomas, food variety company employe, Oakland, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in the Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, October 15, 1960, pg. A1 with question: "Do you believe that the Pirates will lose any cash customers in 1961 because of the way the World Series tickets were..."  Mrs. N. Thomas' answer reads: " I don't think so because the people in Pittsburgh and the surrounding areas are good baseball fans.  And the method of selling the tickets seemed fair to me."  Mrs. M. Thomas' answer reads: "No, I don't think so because this is the first pennant the Pirates have won in 33 years.  I think the people are intelligent enough to know that everybody cannot get into the park."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Nelva Thomas wearing wide lapel coat and tam, standing on Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of Mary Thomas wearing dark knitted cardigan with collar and eyeglasses, standing on Smithfield Street, Downtown
